Column Name: country
child_mort
Description: Death of children under 5 years of age per 1000 live births

Column Name: exports
Description: Exports of goods and services per capita. Given as %age of the GDP per capita

Column Name: health
Description: Total health spending per capita. Given as %age of GDP per capita

Column Name: imports
Description: Imports of goods and services per capita. Given as %age of the GDP per capita

Column Name: Income
Inflation
Description: The measurement of the annual growth rate of the Total GDP

Column Name: life_expec
Description: The average number of years a new born child would live if the current mortality patterns are to remain the same

Column Name: total_fer
Description: The number of children that would be born to each woman if the current age-fertility rates remain the same.

Column Name: gdpp
Description: The GDP per capita. Calculated as the Total GDP divided by the total population.

Column Name: Insights from Pearson's Correlation Coefficient Plot :
Imports have high positive correlation with Exports (+0.74)
Income has fairly high positive correlation with Exports (+0.52)
Life Expectancy has fairly high positive correlation with Income (+0.61)
Total Fertility has very high positive correlation with Child Mortality (+0.85)
GDPP has very high positive correlation with Income (+0.90)
GDPP has fairly high positive correlation with Life Expectancy (+0.60)
Total Fertility has fairly high negative correlation with Life Expectancy (-0.76) - Well
Description: I found this particular thing as an interesting insight but let's not forget "Correlation does not imply causation"!

Column Name: Based on an initial assessment of the average values of each cluster
Description: Cluster 1 could be focus for further analysis. However
column3: when we plot the clusters and look at the graphs
column4: we see that there is overlapping of clusters as well as spread out clusters.

Column Name: Utilising PCA as an alternative did not result in a significant difference.
We've been able to identify some patters in the data and group countries into 3 clusters. However
Description: we should not rely solely on this result to make the recommendation of countries that should receive funding. There are a few alternatives to explore before we can make this recommendation.

Column Name: The implementation of a clustering model in this case did not bring up patters that we might have not found otherwise
column3: it only confirmed general knowledge of intuition about this topic. The clustering can be considered as a preprocessing step and further analysis is required. Here are some alternatives to explore:

Column Name: Learnings
The clustering method alone was not sufficient to provide a final recommendation
Description: however it did contribute to guide actions for further analysis and explore the data in more detail.

Column Name: Further analysis could be done by adding more features related to the context and constraints that the recommended countries might be facing
Description: or systemic challenges that could hinder funding value. Issues like corruption
column3: political/civic society crisis/ natural disasters and other risks could expand this analysis to develop a more suitable criteria for funding depending on the current context of a country beyond these macro indicators.
